posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: My team has an elevator that can score up to L3, but we are considering increasing the height of our elevator so that we can reach L4 and potentially the net. How can we upgrade our elevator to reach our goal? An idea that came up to my mind is to add stages to the elevator, but I am still fairly confused. We are currently using an SDS elevator.

posts.name: Sameer
posts.cooked: How many stages do you currently have on your elevator?

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: I’m assuming that the smallest, innermost stage of the elevator has your scoring mechanism on it. If you were to place the scoring mechanism higher up on that stage (or make a little structure to extend your stage  if its very small, and put it on that) it doesn’t change the total height of the elevator when all the way down, but when all the way up, the scoring mechanism will be higher off the ground.

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked:
if you’re still playing robots on April 8, probably you’re going to champs.

I think it comes down to if you want to do well at champs.  Most likely, All of the other Coral robots will be able to do L4.  Unless you expect to have your own alliance, you’re like most of us, hoping a big-name-team will pick you over the others.   would anyone pick a robot that can’t do L4?

I’m personally of the opinion that your team should continually be improving your robot throughout the season. There are things your robot can do or do better that you know about.   Start doing them.

But there’s always a lot of inertia to keep it the same.  Kids are tired of building things.  Prom.  Jobs.  Warm weather activities.

Yes, you should do L4 if you want to do well. Do you need to listen to me? Nope.

If you’re just going for the ‘fun’ just think how much fun losing is.  In 2012 we were robot number 100 of 100 in Galileo.   It was really discouraging.  And we didn’t fix our known-problems.  my excuse might be because in those days you had to ‘bag’ your robot and working on it was really hard.  we didn’t build a practice bot.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked:
I do not know if your going to champs or not so Ill make a list for both

If you are going to champs, I would recommend not upgrading the elevator. While yes L4 and Barge are somewhat of a necessity at Worlds to do well, the time it takes at he current moment of writing this is to champs is quite small. Adding a new stage to lengthen your elevator is quite risky. You would have to manufacture new parts, maybe need to buy new parts, and wiring and possibly programming as well. There are too many factors that need to be worked on that even if you get the elevator done, your robot could be inconsistent due to rushing to get the elevator built, and inconsistency is often looked down upon in alliance selections.

I would recommend trying to improve existing parts and autos trying to get what you already do to a more consistent level having each one run around 10-12 times without breaking or with a negligible amount of error. This can offset any luck needed to do well at champs.

If you are not going to champs, I would say its up to you. Not doing the elevator upgrade can save you time to do other things such as doing stuff outside of robotics and also saves parts for next year. However, doing the elevator upgrade can prove to be a great offseason project to get new or existing members aquainted to new skills.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5013 Pit Crew and Design (I do not speak for my team, just my opinions)

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: Well so our team made it to state but didn’t qualify for worlds. These are potential modification ideas for our upcoming Invitational competition in October, but I am just trying to brainstorm better ways to score points at that event.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: I also think that it’s a good offseason project because for almost any pick and place game, you will need an elevator (There are exceptions at times though).

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We have three, but we have gotten the issue figured out. We just need to get longer aluminum tubings to move higher because we have all other components.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: It looks like you have a 2-stage elevator, so you’d need to extend the height of both stages. I think your carriage can probably stay the same, which preserves the geometry of the funnel handoff to the end effector.
